Notices are important for strikes and lockouts in essential services, certain transport services and schools. They let the parties reach an agreement to avoid the strike or lockout, and give the other party a chance to make contingency plans. • within 28 days before the start of the intended strike or lockout in an essential service if it will affect the public interest, including public safety or health (the legislation doesn’t define ‘public interest’) and either relates to bargaining for a collective agreement which will bind the employees striking or being locked out, or the strike or lockout relates to an aspect of a collective agreement that the court has declared there is a right to strike or lockout.
• not less than 14 days before the intended strike or lockout if it is an essential service described in Part A of Schedule 1 of the Employment Relations Act 2000; or
• not less than 3 days’ before the intended strike or lockout if it is an essential service described in Part B of Schedule 1 of the Employment Relations Act 2000.
[more]
Some essential services are:
• production, processing, and sale or supply of gas, petroleum or electricity
• hospitals and ambulances
• water supply to cities and districts
• sewage disposal
• port facilities
• the operation of passenger services.
• milk and cream production, distribution and sales.
If there’s a strike or lockout over collective bargaining in an essential service, and the proposed strike will affect the public interest (including public safety or health), a union or employer must give written notice to the other parties within the specified timeframe. Medical retirement must be agreed by you and your employer. They should discuss it with you as a possible option before deciding on dismissal for incapacity. Your employment agreement or workplace policy may have medical retirement provisions, but even if they don’t, you and your employer can still agree to medical retirement (this should be in writing).
Medical retirement usually benefits to both parties. Your employer can hire someone else for the job sooner, and there’s less chance of a personal grievance. For you, the reason for leaving shown in your record of service and in employer references will be medical retirement, not dismissal for incapacity. They should know it’s common for a dismissal for medical incapacity process to several weeks, if not months, and there will be a number of meetings or exchanges of information. This ensures that both parties get the chance to present evidence and give feedback, and that all alternatives are considered. 
Fair process must include:
• Giving you a reasonable time to recover from the injury or illness
• Going through a fair enquiry into your situation, medical prognosis, and ongoing needs before deciding whether to dismiss (they need to balance fairness to you with the needs of the business)
• Notifying you that you could be dismissed
• Giving you a fair chance to give your feedback, suggestions, and thoughts on any proposition
• Taking into account your length of service and whether the job or business contributed to your injury or illness
• Investigating whether there are alternative duties or working arrangements, e.g. staggering your return to work, working from home.

• it’s uncertain whether you’ll return to work or in what capacity; or
• your absence will be too long for the business to reasonably support.
The law doesn’t require your employer to keep you in employment if you’re unable to fulfil your role or do you work due to illness or injury. They need to work out how long they should keep the role open for you. This means understanding how long you’re likely to be off work and whether you’ll be able to do your job again. To do so they should work with you in a positive and supportive way.
Your boss has to follow a fair procedure, e.g. warn you that your job may be at risk if you don’t come back to work. At the same time, they should be clear that trying to understand your medical situation isn’t a disciplinary investigation - you haven’t done anything wrong. They should follow a fair and reasonable process that includes considering a range of factors. If they mishandle it, you could take a personal grievance for unjustified dismissal, unjustified disadvantage, breach of good faith, or breach of contract.
